ygData.subject: More thoughts on IEX
ygData.msgSnippet: Okay, so after I finish making a fixed-enlargement neural network, I have another thought... The way I had originally envisioned the solution to the problem of

Subject: More thoughts on IEX
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=197999825
X-Yahoo-Profile: jarrowwx

Okay, so after I finish making a fixed-enlargement neural network, I
have another thought...

The way I had originally envisioned the solution to the problem of
image enlargement was a complex 2-dimensional formula that uses the
original pixel inputs as 'constants' in the formula.  The formula
creates a 'curve surface' that roughly approximates the original
surface of which the pixel inputs are a representation of.  The
outputs then are calculated by taking the average height of the
surface within an area.

A neural network is a classifier more than a calculator.  But what
about using the NEAT methodology to build a formula?  Use it to evolve
what in compiler terminology (if I'm not mistaken) is a 'parse tree'
of the formula in a manner that is similar to a network.  Each node is
either a value or an operator.  Values have no connections, they are
always the leaf nodes.  Operator nodes have connections to either
value nodes or other operator nodes.  The connection has a weight
which is a multiplier.  So if '+' is connected to 'a' with a weight of
0.5 and to 'b' with a weight of 0.75, then it is the same thing as
0.5a + 0.75b.  A constant input of 1 serves like a bias, so you can
(by means of the weight) build any constant value you need.  And
operators can be any mathematical function.

So, you start with a minimal function.  It just adds all the inputs
together or something.  Then you evolve the parse tree for the
function.  To evaluate the function, you simply take the average of
the values within an (x1,y1,x2,y2) region and see if it corresponds to
the expected pixel value.

Admittedly, the search space for such a thing would be enormous.  And
I doubt that there is a smooth ramp-up that it could follow to help it
evolve.  But I don't know...has anybody read anything useful regarding
evolution of formulas?
